column4: how do I erase a hard drive? what is the command, try to delete files on it but it says i dont have permission
you could unmount the drive, then do 'mkfs' on it ... to learn more, 'man umount', and 'man mkfs'
also, sorry i meant, unmount the _volume_, not the drive
kinda newbie. tried to load 64bit ver last night, but realized some things I need to use arent available, so now I have a bootloader full of crap i dont want

well, out of sight, out of mind, right? so you should be able to edit your boot menu (read docs on your bootloader to find its location) and remove the unwanted entries, and you're done ;-) (that's the "quick and dirty" way, though... not the Right Way)
(in this case, i don't know what the Right Way is, just that what i suggested is not it)
would rather free up hard drive space rather that have 3 distros crowding things
fair enough; in that case, step 0: backup the installation you want to keep ;-)
couldnt i delete everything on that hdd since thats where the mess is then simply edit bootloader>?

and frankly, at today's speeds, it might be fastest to just wipe everthing, and re-install the distro you want, then restore (remount) your (already-separated-in-advance) '/home' and other "keeper" partitions
but you'll learn the least that way (of course, doing it the "hard way" to learn will take quite a while, and much reading)
tried to wipe everything on install, ended up with yet another distro.. lol that was funny what you said
im working in an office dont have time to learn...lol
lol where and how would i edit bootloader?
what i found useful when replacing a whole disk, is to delete the partition table and write it (to ensure it's clean), then reboot into whatever distro's installer CD
anyway, first identify your bootloader (it's probably GRUB, but check to be sure)
its grub
okay, race time: we'll both do 'man grub' and first one to find location of "secret file" wins... GO!
*ding*  /boot/grub/menu.lst
so, browse over to that location ('/boot/grub') and look for 'menu.lst'
open that file with text editor, and ... hm... try to figure it out ;-) i'll read a bit more...
